009package imagingbook.common.tuples;
010
011/**
012 * Elementary implementation of tuples, i.e, ordered sequences
013 * of items of arbitrary types.
014 * Tuples are generally immutable and their main use is to get methods
015 * return multiple values with maximum compile-time safety.
016 * A concrete tuple class is defined for
017 * each "arity", e.g., {@link Tuple2} for 2 elements.
018 * Currently tuple classes for 2, 3 and 4 elements are defined.
019 * <br>
020 * A tuple may be instantiated using either the class constructor, e.g.,
021 * <pre>new Tuple2&lt;Integer, String&gt;(10, "Foo")</pre>
022 * or the associated static method 
023 * <pre>Tuple2.of(10, "Foo")</pre>
024 * Individual tuple elements can be accessed (read-only) by the associated
025 * field names, e.g. {@code f0}, {@code f1} ... etc.
026 * There are no getter methods.
027 * @author WB
028 *
029 */
030public interface Tuple {
031        
032        
033        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
034        
035//      public static void main(String[] args) {
036//              Tuple2<Integer, String> tA = new Tuple2<>(10, "Foo");
037//              Tuple tB = new Tuple2<Integer, String>(-3, "Bar");
038//              Tuple tC = Tuple2.from(17, "Kaputnik");
039//              System.out.println("tA = " + tA.toString());
040//              System.out.println("tB = " + tB.toString());
041//              System.out.println("tC = " + tC.toString());
042//              
043//              int k = tA.get0();
044//              String s = tA.get1();
045//              
046//              System.out.println("tA.f0 = " + tA.get0().toString());
047//              System.out.println("tA.f1 = " + tA.get1().toString());
048//              
049//              System.out.println("tA class = " + tA.getClass());
050//              System.out.println("tB class = " + tB.getClass());
051//              System.out.println("tC class = " + tC.getClass());
052//      }
053}
